intro: Potamogeton helveticus var. balatonicus, commonly known as the Hungarian pondweed, is a submerged aquatic plant native to Europe. It typically grows in freshwater environments such as lakes, ponds, and slow-moving rivers. The plant has long, narrow leaves that are often arranged in whorls around the stem. It produces small, inconspicuous flowers that are usually borne in clusters. This species plays an important role in aquatic ecosystems by providing habitat and food for various aquatic organisms.
